chapter.title: Climate Reconstruction
chapter.para: Climate reconstruction has become an important part of explaining changes in societies. The reconstructions from ice cores and tree rings as well as accumulations on stalactites and rat nests.
The greater the range of types of reconstructions as well as the breadth of geological coverage of climate information expands our understanding of past climate history.

Ice cores, tree rings and stalactite slices are allow called proxies as they are representative of the temperature at the time the at 'layer' was deposited. Ice cores provide a additional benefit from the accumulation of dust and its contents. One of the few ways to distinguish a volcanic winter event from a meteorite event is that a meteorite event usually has micro spears of glass and metal. The micro-spears are thrown up when the body impacts the planet. With a comet impact such spears do not seem to be present
Arizona University website.

In reconstructing the climate of the planet, tree rings provide a picture of the local climate and changes in it. While ice cores paint a picture of the planet as a whole providing a Forest view for the trees view of the trees (You really don't think I would miss that would you?)

sect1.title: Ice Core
sect1.para: The drilling of ice cores in the move 'The day after tomorrow' provide a wonderful window into climate in the hemisphere and together from both the Arctic and Antarctic provide a picture of global weather on a yearly basis. Ice traps dust as well as gases as show deposits. The ice provide isotopes which together with gases and such things as sulfuric acid give information as to the temperature, CO2 content of the air, even the sun's influence via solar flares.

sect2.title: Sulfuric Acid
sect2.para: Sulfuric Acid in the ice is indicative of Volcanic activity.

sect2.title: Nitrate
sect2.para: Nitrates relate to biomass burning measured with Ammonia and solar activity by itself.

sect2.title: Ammonia
sect2.para: Ammonia with nitrates measure burning biomass. Ammonia is also an indicator of cometary impacts.

sect2.title: Dust Particles
sect2.para: Dust particles relate to volcanic activity as well as impact events.

sect2.title: Metallic Spheres
sect2.para: Small silicon and metallic spears relate to impact events as ejected mass for micro spears in the atmosphere.
